p: An example of the use of a filter is the moving average (Chatfield 2004) commonly used for long-term air temperature analysis. This method was used with a 10-, 20-, and 30-year filter to analyze the mean summer air temperatures for the Italian Central Alps (1610–2008; Coppola et al. 2013). For northern Alaska, a 5- and 10-year moving average produced smoothed curves with significant R 2 values for the Barrow data (Fig. 10). Unfortunately, the Toolik data cover only 25 years and have missing data points and a high variability; therefore, the air temperature trend is not significant (p > 0.01) (Fig. 2) and the moving average cannot be used.
